tit.e: FUJIWARA no Ietaka (Junii rank (Junior Second Rank))

sen.j: 藤原 家隆（ふじわら の いえたか、保元3年（1158年） - 嘉禎3年4月9日 (旧暦)（1237年5月5日））は、鎌倉時代初期の公卿、歌人。
sen.e: FUJIWARA no Ietaka (1158-May 5, 1237) was the Kugyo (the top court official) and Kajin poet in early Kamakura era.
FUJIWARA no Ietaka (1158-May 5, 1237) was a Kugyo (top court official) and Kajin poet in the early Kamakura era.
FUJIWARA no Ietaka (1158 - May 5, 1237) was a court noble and Kajin poet in the early Kamakura period.

sen.j: 有職読みで「かりゅう」とも呼ばれる。
sen.e: He was also called as "Karyu" under Yusoku-yomi (expression of respect).
He was also called "Karyu," under Yusoku-yomi (an expression of respect).
He was also called 'Karyu,' under Yusoku-yomi (an expression of respect).

sen.j: 初名、顕隆。
sen.e: The name he had at the beginning was Akitaka (顕隆).
His original name was Akitaka (顕隆).
His original name was Akitaka (顕隆).

sen.j: 法名、仏性。
sen.e: His homyo (Buddhist name) was Bussho (仏性).
His homyo (Buddhist name) was Bussho (仏性).
His homyo (Buddhist name) was Bussho (仏性).

sen.j: 権中納言藤原光隆の子。
sen.e: He was the son of FUJIWARA no Mitsutaka, who had a title of Gon no chunagon (Provisional Middle Councilor).
Ietaka was the son of FUJIWARA no Mitsutaka, who held the title of Gon no chunagon (Provisional Middle Councilor).
Ietaka was the son of FUJIWARA no Mitsutaka, who held the title of Gon Chunagon (a provisional vice-councilor of state).
sen.cmt: 権中納言→Gon Chunagon (a provisional vice-councilor of state) としました。

sen.j: 藤原兼輔の末裔であり、紫式部の遠縁に当たる。
sen.e: He was the descendant of FUJIWARA no Kanesuke and was distantly-related to Murasaki Shikibu.
He was a descendant of FUJIWARA no Kanesuke and a distant relative of Murasaki Shikibu.
He was a descendant of FUJIWARA no Kanesuke and a distant relative of Murasaki Shikibu.

sen.j: 『新古今和歌集』の撰者の一人。
sen.e: He was one of the senja (author) for "Shin Kokin Wakashu" (New Collection of Japanese Poems of Ancient and Modern Times).
He was one of the senja (authors) of "Shin Kokin Wakashu" (New Collection of Japanese Poems of Ancient and Modern Times).
He was one of the senja (authors) of "Shin Kokin Wakashu" (New Collection of Japanese Poems of Ancient and Modern Times).

sen.j: 安元元年（1175年）、叙爵。
sen.e: 1175: He went under Joshaku (conferred a peerage).
1175: Joshaku (conferred a peerage).
In 1175, he was conferred a peerage.
sen.cmt: 文章での表現にしました。

sen.e: 1177: He became a Jiju (chamberlain).
1177: Became a Jiju (chamberlain).
In 1177, he became a Jiju (chamberlain).
sen.cmt: 文章での表現にしました。

sen.j: 各国の国司を併任し、建久4年（1193年）正月、侍従を辞す。
sen.e: He held an additional post as Kokushi (lord) of each province and retired from Jiju position in January 1193.
January 1193: Assigned additional post as Kokushi (provincial lord) and retired from Jiju position.
In February 1193, he was assigned additional post as Kokushi (provincial lord) in various provinces and retired from Jiju position.
sen.cmt: 各国の を追加しました。グレゴリオ暦に修正しました。

sen.j: 正治3年（1201年）正月、従四位。
sen.e: January 1201: He became a Jushii no ge rank (Junior Fourth Rank, Lower Grade).
January 1201: Attained Jushii no ge (Junior Fourth Rank, Lower Grade).
In February 1201, he was promoted to Jushii (Junior Fourth Rank).
sen.cmt: Jushii としました。グレゴリオ暦に修正しました。

sen.j: 元久3年（1206年）、宮内省律令制度下。
sen.e: 1206: He became the Kunaisho (the Ministry of the Sovereign's Household) under the Ritsuryo Ranks and Position.
sen.cmt: 宮内省→Kunaisho(the Ministry of the Sovereign's Household)[http://forums.samurai-archives.com/viewtopic.php?t=3397]
sen.e: 1206: Became a member of the Kunaisho (the Ministry of the Sovereign's Household) under the Ritsuryo Ranks and Position.
In 1206, he was appointed as Kunaikyo (Minister of the Sovereign's Household).
sen.cmt: 原文のwikiを参照し、「宮内省律令制度下」の部分が「宮内卿」とありましたので、左記のようにいたしました。

sen.j: 承久3年（1220年）まで宮内卿を務め、止めたのちに正三位に叙せられた。
sen.e: He served as Kunaikyo until 1220 and was given Jo rank of Shosanmi rank (Senior Third Rank) once retired from that position.
Ietaka served as Kunaikyo until 1220, and once retired from that position was given the Jo rank of Shosanmi (Senior Third Rank).
Ietaka served as Kunaikyo until 1220, and once retired from that position, he was given the rank of Shosanmi (Senior Third Rank).
sen.cmt: 一部翻訳を補足しました。

sen.j: 嘉禎元年（1235年）、参議従二位。
sen.e: 1235: He became the Sangi (Consultant) with a Junii rank (Junior Second Rank).
1235: Became a Sangi (Consultant) with a rank of Junii (Junior Second Rank).
In 1235, he became a Sangi (councilor) with a rank of Junii (Junior Second Rank).

sen.j: 1237年、病を得て79歳で出家した。
sen.e: 1237: He fell ill and became a priest at 79.
1237: Fell ill and became a priest at 79.
In 1237, he fell ill and became a priest at the age of 79.
sen.cmt: 文章での表現にしました。

sen.j: 出家後は摂津国四天王寺に入り、夕陽丘より見える「ちぬの海（大阪湾）」に沈む夕日を好み、その彼方にある極楽へいくことを望んだ。
sen.e: He entered the Shitenno-ji Temple of Settsu no kuni (Settsu Province) and liked the sunset above "Chinu no umi (Osaka Bay)" seen from Yuhigaoka and wished to travel to Gokuraku (Land of Ultimate Bliss) beyond that place.

Ietake entered the Shitenno-ji Temple of Settsu no kuni (Settsu Province) and liked the sunset view above "Chinu no umi (Osaka Bay)" as seen from Yuhigaoka and wished to travel beyond there to Gokuraku (Land of Ultimate Bliss).

Ietake entered the Shitenno-ji Temple of Settsu Province and liked the sunset view above 'Chinu no umi (Osaka Bay)' as seen from Yuhigaoka and wished to travel beyond there to Gokuraku (Land of Ultimate Bliss).

sen.j: 現在、大阪市天王寺区夕陽丘町5に家隆塚（伝藤原家隆墓）がある。
sen.e: There is a tumulus of Ietaka in 5 Yuhigaoka-cho, Tennoji-ku, Osaka City (allegedly a tomb of FUJIWARA no Ietada) present day.
At the present day, there is a tumulus of Ietaka in 5 Yuhigaoka-cho, Tennoji-ku, Osaka City (allegedly the tomb of FUJIWARA no Ietaka).
At the present day, there is a tumulus of Ietaka in 5 Yuhigaoka-cho, Tennoji-ku, Osaka City (allegedly the tomb of FUJIWARA no Ietaka).

sen.j: 和歌を藤原俊成に学んだ。
sen.e: He learned Waka (Japanese poem) under FUJWIARA no Toshinari.
He learned Waka (Japanese poetry) under FUJWIARA no Toshinari.
He learned Waka (Japanese poetry) under FUJIWARA no Toshinari.

sen.j: 寂蓮の婿だったという説もある。
sen.e: There was a theory that he was the groom of Jakuren.
There was a theory that he was the groom of Jakuren.
There was a theory that he was the groom of Jakuren.

sen.j: 歌人としては、晩成型であったが、『六百番歌合』、『正治百首』などに参加して、やがて藤原定家と並び称される歌人として評価されるに至った。
sen.e: He succeeded late for a Kajin poet, but he participated in "Ropyakuban Utaawase" and "Shoji-Hyakushu" and became a Kajin poet reputated to be the one that stood on equal grounds as FUJIWARA no Teika (Sadaie).
He succeeded late for a Kajin poet, but he participated in "Ropyakuban Utaawase" and "Shoji-Hyakushu" and gained a reputaiton as a Kajin poet standing on equal ground with FUJIWARA no Teika (Sadaie).

He succeeded late for a Kajin poet, but he participated in "Roppyakuban utaawase" (The Poetry Match in 600 Rounds) and "Shoji Hyakushu" (Hundred-Poem Sequence of the Shoji Era) and gained a reputation as a Kajin poet standing on equal ground with FUJIWARA no Teika (Sadaie).
sen.cmt: 歌集の補足を追加しました。

sen.j: 承久の乱で隠岐に流された後鳥羽天皇を慰めた。
sen.e: He comforted Emperor Gotoba who was exiled to Oki from Jokyu no ran (Rebellion of Jokyu).
Ietaka gave comfort to Emperor Gotoba, who was exiled to Oki from Jokyu no ran (Rebellion of Jokyu).
Ietaka gave comfort to Emperor Gotoba, who was exiled to Oki in the Jokyu War.

sen.j: 歌風は平明で幽寂な趣きと評価される。
sen.e: His poetic style was pointed out as transpicuous and Yujaku (solitude).
His poetic style has been characterized as transparent and reflecting on the theme of Yujaku (solitude).
His poetic style has been characterized as transpicuous and reflecting on the theme of Yujaku (solitude).

sen.j: 『新勅撰和歌集』には、最高の35首が収められている。
sen.e: Thirty five of his best poems were collected within "Shin Chokusen Wakashu."
Thirty-five of his best poems were collected within "Shin Chokusen Wakashu."
Thirty-five of his best poems were collected within "Shin chokusen wakashu" (New Imperial Anthology of Japanese Poetry).
sen.cmt: 歌集の補足を追加しました。

sen.j: 歌集の『壬二集（みにしゅう）』は六家集の一つ。
sen.e: The Kashu (Collection of Japanese poems) called "Minishu" was one of the Rokkashu (the six great Kashu).
The Kashu (Collection of Japanese poems) called "Minishu" was one of the Rokkashu (the six great Kashu).

sen.j: 息子の藤原隆祐と娘の承明門院小宰相も歌人。
sen.e: His son, FUJIWARA no Takasue and daughter, Kozaisho, who had a title of Shomeimonin, were also Kajin.
